page.title: 01S. TYNESDALE N. OF ALSTON
page.content: The land rises to either side of the South Tyne, west to the high rough fells of Ayle Common; east to the low foothills of the Pennines. The haughs by the river are grazed by cattle and sheep; above them are mixed managed forest, hayfields, rough grazing for sheep, goats and cows, and finally peat and heather covered grouse moors. There are scattered trees and copses up to 350m. There are about 100 residents, mostly farm and snallholding families, with some commuters. Houses are stone, many clustered in the hamlet of Ayle and near the nineteenth century church by the river, others scattered over the hills. Barhaugh Hall is a nineteenth century hunting lodge. The fells are enclosed in areas of several hundred acres by stone dykes, as are the fields on the lower slopes.
